To find the current in the 4 kΩ resistor, we must first determine the state of the diode: whether it is ON or OFF.

Given:
1. \( V_{ON} \) for the diode = 0.7 V.
2. Source current = 1 mA.

When the diode is OFF:
The 2 kΩ and 4 kΩ resistors are in series, so the total resistance will be 6 kΩ. The current through this series combination is 1 mA. So, the voltage drop across the 2 kΩ resistor will be:
\( V = IR = 1mA \times 2kΩ = 2V \).

This means that the voltage at the anode of the diode will be 2V when it's off. Since this is greater than \( V_{ON} \), the diode will turn ON.

When the diode is ON:
The voltage drop across it will be 0.7 V. So, the voltage across the 1 kΩ resistor (which is in parallel with the diode) will also be 0.7 V.

Now, the voltage drop across the 2 kΩ resistor is:
\( V_{2kΩ} = 1mA \times 2kΩ = 2V \).

So, the voltage at the node between the 2 kΩ and 1 kΩ resistors will be:
\( V_{node} = 2V + 0.7V = 2.7V \).

Using the voltage division rule:
\[ V_{3kΩ} = V_{node} \times \frac{3kΩ}{3kΩ + 6kΩ} \]
\[ V_{3kΩ} = 2.7V \times \frac{3}{9} = 0.9V \]

Now, the current through the 3 kΩ resistor is:
\[ I_{3kΩ} = \frac{V_{3kΩ}}{3kΩ} = \frac{0.9V}{3kΩ} = 0.3 mA \]

This current will also flow through the 4 kΩ resistor, as they are in series.

So, the current in the 4 kΩ resistor is 0.3 mA.
